Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 



We at sgSolutions, LLC (SGS) are strongly committed to the safety and protection of our employees, contractors, the public and the environment.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive Process Safety Management (PSM) written program which addresses the fourteen required elements of OSHA's PSM Regulation under 29 CFR 1910.119, including development of Process Safety Information (PSI), completion of Process Hazard Analysis (PHAs), a Mechanical Integrity (MI) and Preventive Maintenance (PM) program, development and annual re-certification of operating procedures, a Management of Change (MOC) process, Pre Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR), and employee training associated with the covered processes at our facility.  Our plant adheres to process safety policies, guidelines, and best practices that have been developed based on company and industry experience.  The management team is committed to the safe operation of the process and the implementation of safe procedures at the facility.



SGS is committed to providing a safe workplace that is operated in an environmentally responsible manner.  SGS is also committed to comply with all applicable laws and regulations relating to safety in the workplace and the protection of the environment.  SGS implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the incident in accordance with our written spill response procedures.  In addition, SGS has implemented an Emergency Response Plan which provides instructions and designates the responsibilities required of all facility personnel in case of plant emergencies. 



SGS maintains a well trained and equipped staff of operators, developed via use of the SGS Operator Assessment Manual which assists plant operators in developing their level of technical proficiency and knowledge of plan

t operations.  Extensive training, demonstration of knowledge and Review Boards with supervision is required within the development plan.  The facility has fully integrated employees in emergency response team.   Appropriate personnel protective equipment including respirators and self-contained breathing apparatus are available onsite for response to emergency situations.





Description and Regulated Substance



The SGS facility is located at 444 W. Sandford Avenue in West Terre Haute, Indiana.  The facility completed construction in 1995 and is located on approximately 14 acres.  Wabash Valley Power Association and Standard General are the owners of SGS.  CB&I provides technical and managerial services on behalf of the owner.  Plant operations and support staff are employed by SGS.  



SGS operates an Air Separation Unit (ASU) that provides nitrogen and oxygen for the gasification process.  SGS also operates a gasification facility using CB&I E-Gas Technology in which coal/petcoke is converted to a synthetic fuel gas (syngas).  The syngas is then used to power a combustion turbine at the Wabash River Combined Cycle Plant located adjacent to SGS.  The syngas is a mixture of gases, including hydrogen.  The maximum amount of syngas on site when the plant is in operation, in the vessels and interconnecting piping, is approximately 34,500 lbs.  The only chemical that exceeds the RMP threshold quantities is hydrogen, which is found in concentrations within the syngas product at greater than 1% when the plant is in operation.  No other regulated substances (toxic or flammables) at the facility are stored or used at quantities which would require compliance with the Risk Management Program.



Hazards Assessments



Hydrogen is the only regulated chemical under the RMP program at the facility. To perform the required offsite consequence analysis for our facility, we have used EPA's RMP*Comp program. Additional specific information on these releases is presented in det

ail in the RMP.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program



SGS has reviewed and revised the documents and procedures for compliance with OSHA's PSM and EPA's Risk Management Program for syngas use and storage.  A management system has been established to maintain the elements of the PSM and Risk Management Programs.  Applicable written elements of the PSM and the Risk Management Program are readily accessible by employees.  Audible alarms located throughout the facility provide reliable notification of syngas (hydrogen) releases.



Five Year Accident History:



In the past five years, one accident occurred. The incident took place on September 14, 2013, at 9:40 pm. During the transition of slurry, piping upstream of the M-120A Mixer failed. The failure occurred approximately five (5) seconds after the water flush began, allowing for the release of gasifier contents to the atmosphere. Operations determined the problem approximately twenty eight (28) seconds after the initial release and pressed the Emergency Shutdown Button. There were no injuries resulting from the incident. Some damage occurred to the slurry piping and to the west side of the slurry heater building.



Emergency Response Program



The SGS plant maintains a written emergency action plan, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition, the plant has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency res

ponse equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to plant processes or other plant facilities. Plant and process modifications are also administered through the MOC and PSSR processes as applicable, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in these changes.  Facility-wide training regarding emergency procedures and evacuation routes occurs on an annual basis.  Annual mock drills are conducted at the facility and frequent communications with local emergency response teams ensure that they are aware of the facility's overall process and hazards.  



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



SGS is committed to continuous improvement and safe operation of its petcoke and or coal gasification system and is in the process of addressing corrective actions deemed necessary.  The facility mechanical integrity preventative maintenance procedures have recently been reviewed/revised and a new tracking system implemented.  The facility is dedicated to resolving all corrective actions from PHAs, and internal and/or external reviews in a timely manner.  SGS maintains documentation of the ongoing progress as related to such items.
